articles.title: About Me
articles.description: Some additional details about the website

articles.title: Kristin Gill
articles.contents:
In my free time, I love surfing, playing soccer, hiking, traveling, and baking/cooking! I am interested in using data and spatial analysis to understand social ecological issues. I am specifically interested in focusing on Latin America and working on my Spanish skills.
I have experience interning with the UCSD Center for Global Justice in Tijuana, Mexico. This internship focused on social ecological issues, such as illegal dumping and erosion due to irregular development in Los Laureles Canyon. When it rains, this canyon often floods and sends sediment and trash into the Tijuana Estuary. Below is an image of an erosion hot spot in Los Laureles canyon.
Los Laureles Canyon Erosion ChannelI also had a sustainability internship at Gaia Servicios Ambientales in Medellín, Colombia, where I improved my conversational Spanish skills. I have experience assisting in GIS research at the Scripps Institution of Oceanography focused on Mexico.

            I am currently pursuing a Master of Environmental Science and Management at the Bren school (UCSB). I graduated magna cum laude from The University of California, San Diego in 2019 with a Bachelor of Science in Environmental Systems (Ecology, Behavior, and Evolution). Through my diverse work experiences, I have become interested in the use of ArcGIS to understand social ecological systems and environmental economic issues. I am interested in further developing my Spanish language skills for use in future jobs and research. At the Bren school, I am pursuing specializations in Economics and Politics of the Environment and Coastal Marine Resource Management.

articles.title: Snowshoe Hares Bonanza Creek, Alaska
articles.contents:
Show code

knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = TRUE, message = FALSE, warning = FALSE)
library(tidyverse)
library(janitor)
library(here)
library(lubridate)
library(ggplot2)
library(kableExtra)
library(knitr)
library(effsize)
library(broom)





Show code

# read in the data
bonanza_hare <- read_csv(here("data_1", "bonanza_hares.csv"))



1. Introduction
This study focuses on analyzing juvenile Snowshoe Hare data from hare trappings at Bonanza Creek Experimental Forest in Alaska from 1999 to 2012 (Kielland et al. 2017). This analysis focuses on three grid locations within the forest, named Bonanza Black Spruce, Bonanza Mature, and Bonanza Riparian. These sites differ based on the types of trees present, and Bonanza Riparian is located next to a river while the other two are not. This report looks at the change in hare trappings over time, the differences in hare weights based on sex and location, and the relationship between juvenile weight and hind foot length.
2. Data and Analyses
Snowshoe Hare physical data were provided by Dr. Kielland and colleagues, who collected the data at the Bonanza Creek Experimental Forest Long Term Ecological Research (LTER) network site near Fairbanks, Alaska (Kielland et al. 2017). The data contain 3,197 observations from capture-recapture studies of hares at three sites from 1999 to 2012. The observations contain information on variables such as sex (m, f, NA), age (juvenile, adult, and mortality), weight (grams), and hind foot length (mm). This report performs a two-sample t-test, with a significance level (\(\alpha\)) of 0.05, to analyze differences in means. The Cohen’s d effect size is also implemented to determine if the difference in means is significant. A linear regression shows the relationship between snowshoe hare weight and hind foot length.
3. Exploratory Findings
A. Annual Juvenile Hare Trap Counts and Descriptive Statistics


Show code

# have data only include hares with age "j"
juvenile_hare <- bonanza_hare %>% 
  filter(age == "j") %>% 
  # change date to ymd and create a column with year
  mutate(date = mdy(date)) %>% 
  mutate(year = year(date))

# separate data set
juvenile_by_year <- juvenile_hare %>% 
  # count by year
  count(year)

# a visualization of the data
ggplot(data = juvenile_by_year, aes(x = year,
                                 y = n)) +
  geom_col(fill = "#009E73") +
  labs(x = "Time (Years)",
       y = "Number of Juvenile Hare Trappings",
       title = "Number of Juvenile Snowshoe Hare Trappings, Bonanza Creek 1999-2012") +
  theme_light()




Figure 1: Figure 1: The number of juvenile snowshoe hare trappings at Bonanza Creek Experimental Forest from 1999 to 2012. The trappings are an indication of population size. Data from: Kielland, K., F.S. Chapin, R.W. Ruess, and Bonanza Creek LTER. 2017. Snowshoe hare physical data in Bonanza Creek Experimental Forest: 1999-Present ver 22. Environmental Data Initiative. https://doi.org/10.6073/pasta/03dce4856d79b91557d8e6ce2cbcdc14





Show code

# summary statistics 
summary_juvenile <- juvenile_by_year %>% 
  summarize(average = mean(n),
            median = median(n),
            minimum = min(n),
            maximum = max(n)) 
kbl(summary_juvenile, caption = "**Table 1:** Summary Statistics for Juvenile Snowshoe Hares") %>%
  kable_styling(latex_options = c("striped", "hold_position"),
                full_width = F)



Table 1: Table 1: Summary Statistics for Juvenile Snowshoe Hares


average


median


minimum


maximum


31.5


18.5


2


126


The number of juvenile snowshoe hare trappings at Bonanza Creek was much lower in 2012 compared to 1999. The maximum number of trappings was 126 (1999) and the minimum was 2 (2010). The average number of juvenile hares trapped each year was 31.5, while the median was 18.5. The amount of effort put in each year may affect these counts. In future analyses, counts should be standardized by the number of days put into trapping snowshoe hares each year.
B. Visualizing Juvenile Hare Weights


Show code

# compare juvenile hare weights by sex and site(grid)
juvenile_weight <- juvenile_hare %>% 
  select(grid, sex, weight) %>% 
  mutate(grid = case_when(
    grid == "bonbs" ~ "Bonanza Black Spruce",
    grid == "bonmat" ~ "Bonanza Mature",
    grid == "bonrip" ~ "Bonanza Riparian")) %>% 
  mutate(sex = case_when(
    sex == "f" ~ "Female",
    sex == "m" ~ "Male"))

# creating visualization
ggplot(data = juvenile_weight, aes(x = sex,
                                   y = weight)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  facet_wrap(~grid) +
  labs(x = "Sex of Juvenile Snowshoe Hares",
       y = "Weight (grams)",
       title = "Weights of Juvenile Snowshoe Hares Compared by Sex and Location") +
  geom_jitter(aes(color = sex), show.legend = FALSE) +
  theme_bw()




Figure 2: Figure 2: The scatterplots for each location show the individual weights of the hares, with color defining male or female. The boxplots on top show the spread and median of the data for males and females at each location. The weight is in grams. The sex was not recorded for some of the juvenile snowshoe hairs, and this is shown as NA. The Bonanza Black Spruce is a location with black spruce trees. The Bonanza Mature location has mature white spruce, paper birch, alder, and black spruce trees. The Bonanza Riparian location is in a flood zone. Data from: Kielland, K., F.S. Chapin, R.W. Ruess, and Bonanza Creek LTER. 2017. Snowshoe hare physical data in Bonanza Creek Experimental Forest: 1999-Present ver 22. Environmental Data Initiative. https://doi.org/10.6073/pasta/03dce4856d79b91557d8e6ce2cbcdc14





Show code

# histogram of mean weights
ggplot(data = juvenile_weight, aes(x = weight)) +
  geom_histogram(aes(fill = sex),
                 bin = 20) +
  labs(x = "Weight (grams)",
       y = "Number of Juvenile Snowshoe Hares",
       title = "Number of Snowshoe Hares by Weight (grams)") +
  facet_wrap(~grid)




Figure 3: Figure 3: The Histograms for each location show the count of snowshoe hares for different weights. The colors differentiate male, female, and NA. Data from: Kielland, K., F.S. Chapin, R.W. Ruess, and Bonanza Creek LTER. 2017. Snowshoe hare physical data in Bonanza Creek Experimental Forest: 1999-Present ver 22. Environmental Data Initiative. https://doi.org/10.6073/pasta/03dce4856d79b91557d8e6ce2cbcdc14



Figure 2 shows that male juvenile snowshoe hares weigh more than female juvenile snowshoe hares.The box plots indicate that while the data are fairly spread, the medians are higher for the male weight compared to the female weight. The horizontal bar across the box on the plot shows the median, and it is higher for males at all three locations. Figure 3 shows the sample sizes vary greatly from location to location, with Bonanza Riparian having the highest sample sizes. The data is more normally distributed for Bonanza Riparian due to the higher sample sizes. More females were trapped than males; females have higher sample sizes/counts.
C. Juvenile Weight Comparison


Show code

# summary statistics: table of means
juvenile_weight_stats <- juvenile_weight %>% 
  filter(weight != "NA") %>%
  group_by(grid, sex) %>% 
  summarize(
    mean = mean(weight),
    sample_size = n(),
    standard_deviation = sd(weight)
  )

kbl(juvenile_weight_stats, caption = "**Table 2:** The summary statistics for juvenile snowshoe hares, including mean, sample size, and standard deviation of weight (grams) for males and females in three locations. The locations are Bonanza Riparian, Bonanaza Mature, and Bonanaza Black Spruce.") %>%
  kable_styling(latex_options = c("striped", "hold_position"),
                full_width = F)



Table 2: Table 2: The summary statistics for juvenile snowshoe hares, including mean, sample size, and standard deviation of weight (grams) for males and females in three locations. The locations are Bonanza Riparian, Bonanaza Mature, and Bonanaza Black Spruce.


grid


sex


mean


sample_size


standard_deviation


Bonanza Black Spruce


Female


1022.0588


34


292.9632


Bonanza Black Spruce


Male


1073.0769


13


222.6408


Bonanza Mature


Female


808.1944


36


361.1235


Bonanza Mature


Male


950.1250


40


314.6864


Bonanza Mature


NA


816.6667


6


307.0939


Bonanza Riparian


Female


824.1496


127


255.0350


Bonanza Riparian


Male


929.2727


110


349.1660


Bonanza Riparian


NA


372.0000


5


258.7856


Show code

# summary of means without grid location
juvenile_weight_mean <- juvenile_weight %>% 
  filter(weight != "NA") %>%
  group_by(sex) %>% 
  summarize(
    mean = mean(weight),
    sample_size = n(),
    standard_deviation = sd(weight)
  )
kbl(juvenile_weight_mean, caption = "**Table 3:** The mean weights (grams), standard deviations, and sample sizes for male and female juvenile snowshoe hares.") %>%
  kable_styling(latex_options = c("striped", "hold_position"),
                full_width = F)



Table 2: Table 3: The mean weights (grams), standard deviations, and sample sizes for male and female juvenile snowshoe hares.


sex


mean


sample_size


standard_deviation


Female


855.3909


197


292.2526


Male


945.8589


163


333.2151


NA


614.5455


11


357.5853




Show code

# Difference in Means
female_mean <- juvenile_weight_mean$mean[1]
male_mean <- juvenile_weight_mean$mean[2]
difference_mean <- male_mean - female_mean





Show code

# vectors for t-test
juvenile_sex <- juvenile_weight %>% 
  select(!grid) %>% 
  filter(weight != "NA")

juvenile_f <- juvenile_sex %>% 
  filter(sex == "Female") %>% 
  pull(weight)

juvenile_m <- juvenile_sex %>% 
  filter(sex == "Male") %>% 
  pull(weight)

# two sample t-test
juvenile_ttest <- t.test(juvenile_f, juvenile_m)
juvenile_ttest_tidy <- tidy(juvenile_ttest)

# Cohen's d
juvenile_effsize <- cohen.d(juvenile_m, juvenile_f)





Show code

# Histograms
ggplot(data = juvenile_weight, aes(x = weight)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 10) +
  facet_wrap(~sex)



Show code

# Quanitle-quantile plot
ggplot(data = juvenile_weight, aes(sample = weight)) +
  geom_qq() +
  facet_wrap(~sex)




For each location, the male juvenile snowshoe hares have higher average weights than the female juvenile snowshoe hares. Overall, the males have a higher mean weight than the females. The difference in means is 90.468 grams. From Welch’s two-sample t-test (t(325.02) = -2.71), the p-value is 0.0071. This is very small and indicates that there is only a 0.71% chance that we could have gotten sample means this different if these sample came from populations with the same mean. This does not give evidence to support the null hypothesis that the difference in means is equal to zero. However, the Cohen’s d test shows us that the effect size is small/moderate-leaning (0.29), so the difference in the means between male and females is not very large. The females had a larger sample size than the males, so this must have impacted the t-test. The effect size is less influenced by the sample size.
D. Relationship between Juvenile Weight and Hind Foot Length


Show code

# juvenile hare weight and hind foot length 
juvenile_weight_hindfoot <- juvenile_hare %>% 
  select(year, weight, hindft, grid, sex) %>% 
mutate(grid = case_when(
    grid == "bonbs" ~ "Bonanza Black Spruce",
    grid == "bonmat" ~ "Bonanza Mature",
    grid == "bonrip" ~ "Bonanza Riparian")) %>% 
  mutate(sex = case_when(
    sex == "f" ~ "Female",
    sex == "m" ~ "Male"))

# correlation graph
ggplot(data = juvenile_weight_hindfoot, aes(x = hindft,
                                            y = weight)) +
  geom_point(aes(color = sex)) +
  labs(x = "Hind Foot Length (mm)",
       y = "Weight (g)",
       title = "Relationship between Juvenile Snowshoe Hare Hind Foot Length (mm) and Weight (g)")




Figure 4: Figure 4: The relationship between juvenile snowshoe hare weight (grams) and hind foot length (mm). Data from: Kielland, K., F.S. Chapin, R.W. Ruess, and Bonanza Creek LTER. 2017. Snowshoe hare physical data in Bonanza Creek Experimental Forest: 1999-Present ver 22. Environmental Data Initiative. https://doi.org/10.6073/pasta/03dce4856d79b91557d8e6ce2cbcdc14





Show code

# Visualizing the linear model
ggplot(data = juvenile_weight_hindfoot, aes(x = hindft,
                                            y = weight)) +
  geom_point(size = 2) +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm",
              color = "red",
              size = 0.5,
              fill = "gray10",
              alpha = 0.5) + 
  theme_light() +
  ggpubr::stat_regline_equation(label.x = 75, label.y = 1200) +
  labs(x = "Hind Foot Length (mm)",
       y = "Weight (g)",
       title = "Relationship between Snowshoe Hare Hindfoot Length (mm) and Weight (g)")




Figure 5: Figure 5: Linear regression desrcibing the relationship betweeen juvenile snowshoe hare weight(g) and hind foot length (mm). Data from 1999 to 2012, collected at the Bonanza Creek LTER. Data from: Kielland, K., F.S. Chapin, R.W. Ruess, and Bonanza Creek LTER. 2017. Snowshoe hare physical data in Bonanza Creek Experimental Forest: 1999-Present ver 22. Environmental Data Initiative. https://doi.org/10.6073/pasta/03dce4856d79b91557d8e6ce2cbcdc14



Show code

# Pearson's r, correlation
hare_cor <- cor.test(juvenile_weight_hindfoot$hindft, juvenile_weight_hindfoot$weight)



A linear regression model was used to consider the relationship between juvenile snowshoe hare weight (g) and hind foot length (mm). A significant regression model was found (\(\beta\) = 9.523, F(1,247) = 105.2, p < 0.001) with an R2 of 0.299. The R2 value tells us that 29.9% of variance in weight (g) is predictable by the hind foot length (mm) of the snowshoe hare. The slope of 9.5 indicates that we expect weight to increase by 9.5 g for each 1 mm increase in hind foot length. The y-intercept of -280 does not make sense in this case because that would mean that hind foot length equals zero and it is impossible to have a negative weight. There is a moderate positive correlation between juvenile snowshoe hare weight and hind foot length (r = 0.55, t(247) = 10.26. The Pearson’s r correlation value ranges from -1 to 1, with negative one indicating a strong negative correlation and positive 1 indicating a strong positive correlation (and zero meaning no correlation). The Pearson’s r is positive in this case because the slope is positive, meaning an increase in hind foot length is related to an increase in weight. The Pearson’s r is r = 0.55, so this is a moderate positive correlation. Some assumptions of the linear model are of concern. The residuals are not very evenly spread/constant along the fitted value. Furthermore, the QQ-plot shows a trend away from linearity at smaller values (-3 to -1). There does not appear to be any extreme outliers, however.
Summary
Initial Findings
Number of juvenile Snowshoe Hare trappings was lower in recent years, with 1999 having the highest number of trappings. This may be related to the amount of effort put in each year.
Juvenile male snowshoe hares weigh more than female snowshoe hares, on average. The differences in sample size may have impacted the t-test because the Cohen’s d test shows us that the effect size is small/moderate-leaning (0.29), meaning the difference in the means between male and females is not very large.
Juvenile snowshoe hare weight and hind foot length are moderately positively correlated (r = 0.55) and this relationship was significant.
Next Steps
Determine the amount of effort put into trapping hares each year to see if this had an impact on the number of hares caught.
Include sex and location in the linear regression analysis.
Data Citation
Kielland, K., F.S. Chapin, R.W. Ruess, and Bonanza Creek LTER. 2017. Snowshoe hare physical data in Bonanza Creek Experimental Forest: 1999-Present ver 22. Environmental Data Initiative. https://doi.org/10.6073/pasta/03dce4856d79b91557d8e6ce2cbcdc14

articles.title: Kristin Gill
articles.contents:
EDUCATION
Master of Environmental Science and Management, (Expected June 2022)
Bren School of Environmental Science & Management – University of California, Santa Barbara (UCSB)
Specialization: Economics and Politics of the Environment and Coastal Marine Resource Management
Focus: Strategic Environmental Communication and Media
Highlighted Coursework: Writing Skills for Environmental Professionals, GIS, Data Visualization
Bachelor of Science in Environmental Systems, 3.86 GPA (June 2019)
University of California, San Diego (UCSD)
Honors/Awards: Provost Honors, Phi Beta Kappa Honor Society, Golden Key International Honor Society, National Society of Leadership and Success, award for proposing a UCSD Bike-Share program
Leadership/Involvement: InterVarsity Leadership and Vision Team
ENVIRONMENTAL EXPERIENCE
Research Assistant – Scripps Institution of Oceanography, San Diego, CA (9/19–3/20)
Assisted in a suitability analysis for dive sites in Mexico, using ArcGIS Pro, to determine the most accessible dive sites in Mexico, considering factors like proximity to airports and types of roads nearby
Constructed a reproducible workflow in Python to merge and clean 30 Excel sheets of census data
Created the first map of formal and informal fishing ports in Mexico, using ArcGIS and Google Earth, to contribute to the suitability analysis that will be part of a published paper by the Aburto Lab
Sustainability Intern – Gaia Servicios Ambientales, Medellín, Colombia (7/19–9/19)
Consolidated greenhouse gas emissions data in Excel for 5+ Colombian companies to use to calculate total greenhouse gas emissions for each company
Researched Science Based Targets calculation methods, creating a comprehensive PowerPoint in English and Spanish to be used by managers for client presentations
Improved professional and conversational Spanish skills by communicating daily with coworkers and participating in work events, including a volunteer tree-planting project
Recommended methods for jean and motorcycle factories to reduce waste
Education Intern – I Love A Clean San Diego (ILACSD), San Diego, CA (9/18–6/19)
Created an environmental curriculum focused on food and plastic waste for Girl and Boy Scout troops, and presented the material to a Daisy troop
Solicited donations from businesses for the Zero Waste Fair raffle fundraiser, receiving donations from 5+ businesses, including over 100 reusable Stasher bags
Utilized Canva weekly to create flyers for events and informational e-handouts that were used to advertise for workshops and as educational materials at workshops
Set up the aerial artwork and facilitated adding kids to the design, as part of a team, for Kids’ Ocean Day
Blum Summer Field Intern – UCSD Center on Global Justice, San Diego, CA/Tijuana, MX (6/18–8/18)
Recorded interviews with 8+ residents about flooding and erosion in 3 underserved communities of Los Laureles Canyon, marking GPS coordinates to include in supervisor’s PhD dissertation
Authored a 5-page report, as part of a team, on the work accomplished and provided ideas for the future
Mapped 3 erosion hotspots in Los Laureles Canyon, using Google Earth, to visualize areas that deliver the most sediment to the Tijuana Estuary
Plant With Purpose, San Diego, CA (9/17–3/18)
Development Assistant (11/17–3/18)
Managed the Customer Relationship Management (CRM) database (Bloomerang) with high attention to detail to ensure accurate and updated donor information for over 1,000 donors
Mailed and emailed donation receipts to each donor every week, utilizing Bloomerang
Connected Plant With Purpose’s Bay Area regional representative with Rotary of San Jose
Documented Major Donor Team Performance metrics and distributed them to the team weekly to encourage fun, healthy competition and focus on meeting fundraising targets
Grant Writing Intern (9/17–11/17)
Edited 20+ proposals, cover letters, and reports
Drafted a grant proposal to secure funding for the non-profit
Became familiar with Bloomerang, Wiki, Foundation Directory Online, 990s/annual reports
ADDITIONAL EXPERIENCE
Legal Assistant – Law Offices of Timothy Gill, San Jose, CA (4/20–9/20)
Authored legal documents: settlement statements and demand letters; called insurance companies, chiropractic offices, and police departments to obtain up-to-date information on cases
SKILLS, CERTIFICATIONS, & INTERNATIONAL EXPERIENCE
Computer: R/Rstudio, ArcGIS Pro, Google Earth, Outlook, Python, Word, Excel, Canva, Bloomerang
Language: Native English, intermediate Spanish
Certifications: Fundamentals of GIS; Geospatial and Environmental Analysis; Python Data Structures; Programming for Everybody (Getting Started with Python); Imagery, Automation, and Applications
International Experience: Study Abroad: Revelle in Rome; University of Oxford, Smith School of Enterprise and the Environment Summer Program (6/19-7/19); Amazon Riverboat Expedition Iquitos, Peru
